data.name: Supplier_SupplierInformationSummary_Hint
data.value: To complete each section, tell us about:

data.name: Supplier_SupplierInformationSummary_BeforeStart_Hint
data.value: To find out what information you need to provide and why:

data.name: SupplierInformation_WhatSupplierInformationIs_Message
data.value:
Suppliers must provide contracting authorities with certain information under the Procurement Act 2024 if they want to bid on a public procurement. The information is not specific to one bid and can be used repeatedly if it hasn’t changed.

The supplier information section of this service replaces the supplier questionnaire. It allows suppliers to fill out the required information and create a share code or pdf file to supply to the contracting authority when bidding on a procurement.

If a contracting authority wants more information specific to a procurement, they will include a procurement specific questionnaire (opens in new tab) in the bid pack.

Watch the guide for suppliers video (opens in a new tab).

data.name: SupplierInformation_WhenToUpdateSupplierInformation_Heading
data.value: When to update your supplier information

data.name: SupplierInformation_WhenToUpdateSupplierInformation_Message
data.value:
You’ll be asked for your supplier information in the form of a share code or file when you bid for a public procurement.

Your supplier information is saved in this service. You only need to update it when information changes.

You can update your supplier information whenever it changes but you must create a new share code and file to share the new information.

data.name: SupplierInformation_WhenYourInformationIsSaved_Message
data.value:
You don’t have to enter your supplier information in one go but your information is only saved when you click a ‘save’ button.

In some sections, you can save after one or 2 pages. In other sections, it may be 10 or more pages before you can save your information.

If you start a section but haven’t clicked the ‘save’ button, your information will be lost if you:

  • close your browser
  • navigate away from the service
  • leave the page unattended for more than an hour

data.name: SupplierInformation_InformationYouNeed_Heading
data.value: The information you need for each section

data.name: SupplierInformation_InformationYouNeed_Message
data.value:
Your organisation

Each of these sections within ‘Your organisation’ can be saved independently. You can complete one and save it and then come back to complete another.

Where a question isn’t relevant, you need to answer ‘no’ to complete the section.

For the whole ‘Your organisation’ section, you’ll need:

  • the name of your organisation or the name you trade under
  • your organisation’s registered address
  • your business postal address, if different or if you aren’t a registered company
  • a registry number if you have one, for example a Companies House number or a Charity number
  • your VAT number, if you have one
  • whether your organisation is a:
    • small or medium-sized enterprise (SME)
    • voluntary, community and social enterprise (VCSE)
    • supported employment provider
    • public service mutual
  • the legal formation of your company and the law that defines it. For example, a private limited company under the Companies Act 2006.

People connected to your organisation

A 'connected person' is someone who influences or controls your company. It includes ‘people of significant control’ and any other individual, group or company that has a declarable interest in your business.

For example, a director, a trustee of a trust, a majority shareholder or a parent or subsidiary company.

If your company isn’t influenced or controlled by anyone you need to answer ‘no’ to complete the section.

You can only add one connected person at a time. The information you complete will depend on who the ‘person’ is and how they’re connected to your organisation.

For organisations, you'll need:

  • the name of the connected organisation
  • its registered address
  • its business postal address, if different
  • the legal formation of the organisation and the law that defines it. For example, a private limited company under the Companies Act 2006.
  • its company number if registered with Companies House, or non-UK equivalent
  • if the organisation is a registered company or any other organisation with significant influence or control, you need:
    • how the organisation is connected to yours. For example, owns shares or has voting rights.
    • the date it was registered as a person of significant control
    • the name of the register

For individuals or trustees, you'll need:

  • their name, date of birth and nationality
  • their business postal address
  • how they are connected to your organisation. For example, owns shares or has voting rights.
  • the date they were registered as a person of significant control
  • the name of the register

Any general qualifications your organisation holds

If you don't have any general qualifications to share you need to answer ‘no’ to complete the section.

If you do have any general qualification to share, you'll need:

  • the qualification name
  • who awarded the qualification
  • the date it was awarded

Contracting authorities will usually ask for qualifications that are specific to a procurement in the bid pack with instructions on how to provide the information.

Any general trade assurances your oganisation holds

If you don't have any general trade assurances to share you need to answer ‘no’ to complete the section.

If you do have any general trade assurances to share, you'll need:

  • the name of organisation that awarded the trade assurance
  • a reference number if you have one
  • the date it was awarded

Contracting authorities will usually ask for trade assurances that are specific to a procurement in the bid pack with instructions on how to provide the information.

Anything that may exclude your organisation from procurement

If there isn’t anything that may exclude your organisation from public procurement you need to answer ‘no’ to complete the section.

If you have an exclusion to declare, you'll need:

  • to say whether the exclusion happened in the UK or not
  • what the exclusionary penalty, conviction or other event was
  • who the exclusion applied to. For example, your organisation or a person connected to your organisation.
  • an email address a contracting authority can use to contact you about the exclusion
  • a description of what led to the exclusion
  • how the exclusion is managed including any penalty or fine, steps taken to stop it happening again and how they are being monitored
  • any supporting documentation you have. For example, documentation from the police, HMRC or the court.
  • if the decision is recorded on a public authority website, that website address
  • the date the circumstances that led to the exclusion ended

Your organisation’s recent financial information

If your accounts were audited:

  • upload one or more files with your most recent 2 financial years, or most recent year if you don’t have 2
  • the financial year end date of the information uploaded

If your accounts were not audited:

  • upload one or more files with account or financial statements for:
    • your most recent 2 financial years, or your most recent year if you don’t have 2
    • a statement showing your organisation’s financial standing if you do not have a full year of accounts
  • the financial year end date of the information uploaded

data.name: SupplierInformation_HowToShare_Heading
data.value: How to share your supplier information

data.name: SupplierInformation_HowToShare_Message
data.value:
When you bid on a public procurement, you’ll be asked to provide a share code or pdf file of your supplier information.

When you create a share code a snapshot of your supplier information is stored against the code, and a pdf file of the information is available to download.

The contracting authority will specify in the bid pack how they want to receive your supplier information.

They may ask you to put the share code into their e-procurement system, also called an eSender. For example, Atamis or Jaggaer.

Alternatively, you may be asked to email a pdf file of your supplier information which you can download from the ‘Declare and create a share code’ section.

You can update your supplier information whenever it changes but you must create a new share code and file to share the new information.

data.name: Supplementary_CookieDetails_Title
data.value: Details about cookies on Find a Tender

data.name: Supplementary_CookieDetails_Intro
data.value: Find a Tender puts small files (known as ‘cookies’) onto your computer to collect information about how you browse the site. Find out more about the cookies we use, what they’re for and when they expire.

data.name: Supplementary_CookieDetails_GoogleAnalytics
data.value: We use Google Analytics software to collect anonymised information about how you use Find a Tender. We do this to help make sure the site is meeting the needs of its users and to help us make improvements to the site.

data.name: Supplementary_CookieDetails_NoGoogleShare
data.value: We do not allow Google to use or share the data about how you use this site.

data.name: Supplementary_CookieDetails_ListItem1
data.value: how you got to the site

data.name: Supplementary_CookieDetails_ListItem2
data.value: the pages you visit on GOV.UK and how long you spend on them

data.name: Supplementary_CookieDetails_ListItem3
data.value: what you click on while you’re visiting the site

data.name: Supplementary_CookieDetails_ListItem4
data.value: Google Analytics sets the following cookies.

data.name: Supplementary_CookieDetails_SignedInInfo
data.value: When you sign in to the service, we’ll set cookies to keep you signed in as you use the site. These cookies do not store your personal data and are deleted when you close your browser.

data.name: Supplementary_CookieDetails_BannerInfo
data.value: You may see banners when you visit Find a Tender inviting you to select your cookie preferences. We’ll set cookies so that your computer knows you’ve seen such messages and not to show them again, and also to store your settings.

data.name: Supplementary_CookieDetails_ChangeSettingsInfo
data.value: You can change which cookies you're happy for us to use.

data.name: Supplementary_CookieDetails_TableRow_GA
data.value: This cookie is used with Google Analytics. This cookie allows Google to track unique users via a client identifier that is randomly generated

data.name: Supplementary_CookieDetails_TableRow_GAT
data.value: This cookie is used with Google Analytics. It is used to reduce the number of page view requests.

data.name: Supplementary_CookieDetails_TableRow_GID
data.value: This cookie is used with Google Analytics. It helps us count how many people visit the service by telling us if you’ve visited before.

data.name: Supplementary_CookieDetails_TableRow_Antiforgery
data.value: This cookie keeps the service secure, preventing cross-site forgery requests.

data.name: Supplementary_CookieDetails_TableRow_Cookies
data.value: Stores details of the currently authenticated user.

data.name: Supplementary_CookieDetails_TableRow_Culture
data.value: Stores the currently selected language requirement.

data.name: Supplementary_Cookies_Intro1
data.value: Cookies are files saved on your phone, tablet or computer when you visit a website.

data.name: Supplementary_Cookies_Intro2
data.value: We use cookies to store information about how you use the Find a Tender website, such as the pages you visit.

data.name: Supplementary_Cookies_Settings_Intro
data.value: We use 2 types of cookie. You can choose which types you’re happy for us to use, except for those that are essential.

data.name: Supplementary_Cookies_GoogleAnalytics
data.value: We use Google Analytics to measure how you use the website so we can improve it based on user needs. We do not allow Google to use or share the data about how you use this site.

data.name: Supplementary_Cookies_GoogleAnalyticsInfo
data.value: Google Analytics sets cookies that store anonymised information about:

data.name: Supplementary_Cookies_ListItem1
data.value: how you got to the site

data.name: Supplementary_Cookies_ListItem2
data.value: the pages you visit on Find a Tender and how long you spend on each page

data.name: Supplementary_Cookies_ListItem3
data.value: what you click on while you’re visiting the site

data.name: Supplementary_Cookies_UseCookies
data.value: Use cookies that measure my website use

data.name: Supplementary_Cookies_DoNotUseCookies
data.value: Do not use cookies that measure my website use

data.name: Supplementary_Cookies_StrictlyNecessary_Info1
data.value: These essential cookies do things like remember when you are signed in, the language you want to view the site in, and the notifications you’ve seen so we do not show them to you again.

data.name: Supplementary_Cookies_StrictlyNecessary_Info2
data.value: They always need to be on.

data.name: Supplementary_Cookies_FindOutMore
data.value: Find out more about cookies on Find a Tender

data.name: Supplementary_Cookies_GovServices_Info
data.value: Most services we link to are run by different government departments, for example DWP’s Universal Credit online, DVLA’s vehicle tax service, or HMRC’s webchat. These services may set additional cookies and, if so, will have their own cookie policy and banner linking to it.

data.name: ShareYourInformation_HowItWorksParagraph1
data.value: To share your supplier information with buyers you need to create a share code and file, and declare that the information is correct.

data.name: ShareYourInformation_HowItWorksParagraph2
data.value: This saves a snapshot of the supplier information you provided about your organisation, connected persons, exclusions and financial information.

data.name: ShareYourInformation_HowItWorksParagraph3
data.value: When you submit a bid for a procurement, the contracting authority will let you know how to give them the share code or file.

data.name: ShareYourInformation_HowItWorksParagraph4
data.value: You can update your supplier information whenever it changes but you must create a new share code and file to share the new information.

data.name: ShareYourInformation_ShareCodeCreatedFooterBody2

data.name: Exclusions_AddExclusionDeclaration_Title
data.value: Add any mandatory and discretionary exclusions

data.name: Exclusions_AddExclusionDeclaration_Paragraph1
data.value: You must tell us if there are any circumstances that may exclude you as a supplier from the procurement process because your organisation or a connected person committed an offence.

data.name: Exclusions_AddExclusionDeclaration_Paragraph2
data.value: Offences are listed as 'mandatory exclusion grounds' and 'discretionary exclusion grounds' in the Procurement Act 2023.

data.name: Exclusions_AddExclusionDeclaration_InsetText
data.value: If any exclusions apply to a person with significant control, such as a director or majority shareholder, make sure you have added them as a connected person.

data.name: Exclusions_AddExclusionDeclaration_Paragraph3
data.value: You'll need to provide details about each exclusion, such as where it happened and who it applies to and upload any supporting documents you may have.

data.name: Exclusions_AddExclusionDeclaration_MandatoryExclusionsIntro
data.value: Penalties and other events that may exclude you are:

data.name: Exclusions_AddExclusionDeclaration_MandatoryExclusions_Penalty1
data.value: adjustments for tax arrangements that are abusive

data.name: Exclusions_AddExclusionDeclaration_MandatoryExclusions_Penalty3
data.value: defeat in respect of notifiable tax arrangements

data.name: Exclusions_AddExclusionDeclaration_MandatoryExclusions_Penalty4
data.value: failure to cooperate with an investigation

data.name: Exclusions_AddExclusionDeclaration_MandatoryExclusions_Penalty5
data.value: finding by HMRC, in exercise of its powers in respect of VAT, of abusive practice

data.name: Exclusions_AddExclusionDeclaration_MandatoryExclusions_Penalty6
data.value: penalties for transactions connected with VAT fraud and evasion of tax or duty

data.name: Exclusions_AddExclusionDeclaration_MandatoryExclusions_Penalty7
data.value: penalties payable for errors in tax documentation and failure to notify, and certain VAT and excise wrongdoing

data.name: Exclusions_AddExclusionDeclaration_MandatoryConvictionsIntro
data.value: Convictions that may exclude you are:

data.name: Exclusions_AddExclusionDeclaration_MandatoryConvictions_Conviction1
data.value: ancillary offences - aiding, abetting, encouraging or assisting crime

data.name: Exclusions_AddExclusionDeclaration_MandatoryConvictions_Conviction4
data.value: labour market, slavery and human trafficking offences

data.name: Exclusions_AddExclusionDeclaration_MandatoryConvictions_Conviction7
data.value: terrorism and offences having a terrorist connection

data.name: Exclusions_AddExclusionDeclaration_MandatoryExclusionsLinkText
data.value: These exclusions are defined in schedule 6 of the Procurement Act 2023 (opens in new tab).

data.name: Exclusions_AddExclusionDeclaration_DiscretionaryExclusionsIntro
data.value: Discretionary exclusions that may exclude you are:

data.name: Exclusions_AddExclusionDeclaration_DiscretionaryExclusions_Exclusion2
data.value: breach of contract and poor performance

data.name: Exclusions_AddExclusionDeclaration_DiscretionaryExclusions_Exclusion4
data.value: infringement of Competition Act 1998, under Chapter II prohibition

data.name: Exclusions_AddExclusionDeclaration_DiscretionaryExclusions_Exclusion7
data.value: potential competition and competition law infringements

data.name: Exclusions_AddExclusionDeclaration_DiscretionaryExclusions_Exclusion9
data.value: suspension or ceasing to carry on all or a substantial part of a business

data.name: Exclusions_AddExclusionDeclaration_DiscretionaryExclusionsLinkText
data.value: These exclusions are defined in schedule 7 of the Procurement Act 2023 (opens in new tab).

data.name: Consortium_ConsortiumStart_Paragraph2
data.value: As the person creating the consortium, only you will be able to add or change information.

data.name: Consortium_ConsortiumStart_Paragraph3
data.value: To create a consortium you'll need:

data.name: Consortium_ConsortiumStart_Paragraph3_list
data.value:
• to give it a unique name
  • a postal address
  • an email address
  • your most recent share code
  • the most recent share codes for all the other suppliers

data.value: Any supplier you want to add to the consortium must have completed their supplier information and created a share code.

data.name: Consortium_ConsortiumStart_Paragraph5

data.name: MoU_ReviewAndSign_Confirm_Title

data.name: MoU_ReviewAndSign_Hint
data.value:
The data sharing agreement is a memorandum of understanding (MOU) about data shared on the Find a Tender service (FTS) and the joint responsibilities of:

  • the Cabinet Office
  • contracting authorities taking part in public procurement

The MOU explains the:

  • personal and sensitive data collected on FTS
  • role and responsibilities of the Cabinet Office
  • role and responsibilities of the contracting authority

data.name: MoU_ReviewAndSign_Download_Hint
data.value: Download and share the document within your organisation. When ready, return to this page to confirm that your organisation understands its responsibilities as a joint data controller.

data.name: MoU_ReviewAndSign_Options_Hint
data.value:
By ticking the box you are 'signing' the data sharing agreement on behalf of your organisation. The details you provide will be saved and dated as proof of agreement with the MOU.

You'll be able to view the document and signing information from your organisation details page.

data.name: ConsortiumShareMyInformation_HowItWorksParagraph1

data.value: When you submit a bid for a procurement, the contracting authority will let you know how to give them the share code or file.

data.name: ConsortiumShareMyInformation_HowItWorksParagraph3
data.value:
If any of the supplier information for an organisation in the consortium changes, it must create a new share code.

You must update its share code and create a new combined share code and file to share the new information.
